txt.en: 'I think we are nearing the end of the path!'
'I will be pleased to be away from this accursed hut. Let us go and quickly.'
'The hut is just around the bend!'

'Are you prepared, [placeholder]? With this hag's ties to Saruman and the evil creatures haunting these fells, I fear the Old Woman of the Mountain may be more than just a simple old mountain-woman.\n\n'Be wary!'
Instance: The Old Woman of the Mountain
'This is becoming wearying....'
'It is time to deal with Gwyllion!'
Saeradan has perished
You have failed
Gwyllion has retreated
Speak with Saeradan at Gwyllion's Gate.
Saeradan has been defeated
Seek out Gwyllion at her hut beyond Gwyllion's Gate.
Speak with Saeradan to return to Echad Saeradan.
'Be strong, Malh-gavar!'
'Old Woman, we demand that you leave the people of the Uch-lûth in peace...Saruman the Treasonous has no cause to bring such terror upon them!'
'Gwyllion! Return and face us! Gwyllion!'
Accompany Saeradan to confront Gwyllion
Accompany Saeradan to confront Gwyllion
Talk to Saeradan
Defeat Gwyllion and her lieutenants
Defeat Gwyllion and her lieutenants
Talk to Saeradan
Saeradan must survive
'Cymunu, bring an end to this!'
'No! My pets! You shall pay for that, Duvodiad!'
Saeradan has charged you with confronting Gwyllion, the Old Woman of the Mountain, and driving her forth from the Windfells of Enedwaith.
'The White Hand will not be thwarted!'
'The White Hand shall crush the life from the filthy riders, just as I will crush the life from you, Duvodiad....'
'Malh-gavar! Cymunu! Deal with this duvodiad....'
'Beware! I sense something evil ahead...!'
'I fear this Old Woman has set her evil will upon us!'
'Yet another trap!'
'Perhaps we should have taken the other branch!'
'Perhaps we should have taken the other branch!'
'This is becoming wearying....'
'Gwyllion has escaped, [placeholder]. While she may no longer bring terror to the Uch-lûth, I fear we have not yet seen the last of her.\n\n'Speak with me again when you are ready to leave.'
'You intrude upon my home in the name of the infidels of the North, friends of the Horse-folk!'
